[TITLE]
<line: 4> IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
<line: 5> FOR THE DISTRICT OF MARYLAND 

[TITLE]
<line: 7> RAHYMEEN JAMEL BARBER, SR. 
<line: 8>  #365-763, #245-5451 

[TEXT]
<line: 10> Petitioner 

[TEXT]
<line: 12> Civil Action No. DKC-17-2491 

[TEXT]
<line: 14> v. 

[TITLE]
<line: 16> RICKEY FOXWELL, and 
<line: 17> THE ATTORNEY GENERAL OF THE 
<line: 18> STATE OF MARYLAND 

[TEXT]
<line: 20> Respondents 

[TEXT]
<line: 22> * 

[TITLE]
<line: 24> MEMORANDUM OPINION 

[TEXT]
<line: 26> Petitioner Rahymeen Jamel Barber, Sr., challenges his convictions for sexual abuse of a 
<line: 27> minor, second degree rape, and other offenses in this petition for a writ of habeas corpus filed 
<line: 28> pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 2254.  Respondents assert the petition should be denied and dismissed.  
<line: 29> (ECF No. 4).  Mr. Barber has not filed a reply. 

[TEXT]
<line: 31> The issues have been briefed and there is no need for an evidentiary hearing.  See Rule 
<line: 32> 8(a), Rules Governing Section 2254 cases in the United States District Courts; Local Rule 105.6 
<line: 33> (D. Md. 2018); see also Fisher v. Lee, 215 F.3d 438, 455 (4th Cir. 2000) (stating a petitioner is not 
<line: 34> entitled to hearing under 28 U.S.C. § 2254(e)(2)).  For the reasons set forth below, the court will 
<line: 35> deny and dismiss the petition with prejudice. 

[TITLE]
<line: 37>    PROCEDURAL HISTORY 

[TEXT]
<line: 39> Mr. Barber was convicted after a jury trial in the Circuit Court for Wicomico County of 
<line: 40> sexually abusing his minor stepdaughter.  ECF No. 4-3 pp.42-43.  He was sentenced to a total of 
<line: 41> fifty years of incarceration on October 22, 2010.  ECF No. 4-1 pp. 11-14. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 2 of 35

[TITLE]
<line: 4> I.  
<line: 5> Direct Appeal 

[TEXT]
<line: 7> Mr. Barber appealed his conviction to the Court of Special Appeals of Maryland, 
<line: 8> presenting one question:  “Whether the trial court erred in allowing other ‘bad acts’ into evidence 
<line: 9> and/or erred in denying the motion for mistrial?” See Rahymeen J. Barber v. State of Maryland, 
<line: 10> No. 2238, Sept. Term, 2010 (filed June 13, 2012) at ECF No. 4-4.  The Court of Special Appeals 
<line: 11> affirmed his convictions.  Id.  On September 24, 2012, the Court of Appeals of Maryland denied 
<line: 12> Mr. Barber’s petition for a writ of certiorari.  Barber v State, 428 Md. 544 (2012). 

[TEXT]
<line: 14> II. 
<line: 15> Post-Conviction Proceedings 

[TITLE]
<line: 17> A.  
<line: 18> Petition for Post-Conviction Relief 

[TEXT]
<line: 20> Mr. Barber, then self-represented, had earlier filed a petition for post-conviction relief in 
<line: 21> the Circuit Court for Wicomico County, Maryland on July 27, 2012, which was later supplemented 
<line: 22> by his counsel on June 5, 2013, presenting the following claims of ineffective assistance of trial 
<line: 23> counsel:  

[TEXT]
<line: 25> I. 
<line: 26> Counsel was ineffective for failure to investigate the State’s medical expert 
<line: 27> testimony and violated Mr. Barber’s right to due process by failing to offer a viable 
<line: 28> defense.  

[TEXT]
<line: 30> A. 
<line: 31> Counsel provided ineffective assistance in failing to investigate the 
<line: 32> State’s medical expert testimony that was central to the jury’s credibility 
<line: 33> assessment of the victim.[1] 
<line: 34> B. 
<line: 35> The admission of inaccurate and misleading scientific evidence 
<line: 36> violates the due process clause. 

[TEXT]
<line: 38> II. 
<line: 39> Counsel rendered ineffective assistance for failure to object to the victim’s 
<line: 40> inadmissible prior inconsistent statements; for failure to object when the State made 
<line: 41> rehabilitative remarks during their opening statement; and failure to request a 
<line: 42> limiting instruction. 

[TEXT]
<line: 44> 1   Portions of the state record refer to the victim by her full name or first name and first initial 
<line: 45> of her last name and are unredacted.  In light of the sensitive nature of the issues and to protect 
<line: 46> personal information about the victim, Respondents’ exhibits docketed at ECF Nos. 4-1, 4-2, 4-3, 
<line: 47> 4-4, 4-5, 4-6, 4-7, 4-8 will be placed under seal.  

[ABANDON]
<line: 49> 2 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 3 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> A. 
<line: 5> Counsel rendered ineffective assistance for failure to object to out 
<line: 6> of court statements made by the victim to others under Maryland Rule 5-
<line: 7> 802.1. 
<line: 8> B. 
<line: 9> Counsel rendered ineffective assistance for failure to object when 
<line: 10> the State made rehabilitative remarks in their opening statement and failed 
<line: 11> to challenge the admissibility of prior out-of-court statements under Md 
<line: 12> Rule 5-616(c)(2). 
<line: 13> C. 
<line: 14> Counsel rendered ineffective assistance for failure to request a 
<line: 15> limiting instruction that prior inconsistent statements offered by the social 
<line: 16> workers, the doctor, and the mother were not intended for their truth that 
<line: 17> the abuse actually occurred. 

[TEXT]
<line: 19> III. 
<line: 20> Defense counsel rendered ineffective assistance for failure to object to a 
<line: 21> witness commenting on the truthfulness of the victim. 

[TEXT]
<line: 23> IV. 
<line: 24> Defense counsel rendered ineffective assistance for failing to object to the 
<line: 25> State's presentation of expert testimony about delayed reporting and 
<line: 26> accommodation in child sexual abuse cases. 

[TEXT]
<line: 28> V. 
<line: 29> Defense counsel rendered ineffective assistance for failure to file a motion 
<line: 30> for reconsideration of sentence. 
<line: 31> VI. 
<line: 32> Defense counsel rendered ineffective assistance for failure to file an 
<line: 33> application for review of sentence by a three-judge panel. 

[TEXT]
<line: 35> ECF No. 4-5 pp. 17-18; ECF No. 4-7 p. 3. 
<line: 36> The Circuit Court held a hearing on the post-conviction petition on September 12, 2013.  

[TEXT]
<line: 38> ECF No. 4-6.  The Circuit Court granted Mr. Barber leave to file a motion for modification of 
<line: 39> sentence and an application for review of sentence by a three judge panel, but denied relief as to 
<line: 40> all other claims on November 8, 2013.  ECF No. 4-7 p. 19. 

[TITLE]
<line: 42> B.  
<line: 43> Application for Leave to Appeal Denial of Post-Conviction Relief 

[TEXT]
<line: 45> Mr. Barber filed an application for leave to appeal the denial of post-conviction relief which 
<line: 46> presented two arguments:  (1) the “post-conviction court erred when it ruled trial counsel was not 
<line: 47> ineffective for failing to object to multiple recitations of the child’s accusations and vouching for 

[ABANDON]
<line: 49> 3 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 4 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> her credibility” and (2) the “post-conviction court erred when it ruled that trial counsel was not 
<line: 5> ineffective for failing to challenge an inaccurate report of possible child sexual abuse, but rather 
<line: 6> reasonable trial strategy.”  ECF No. 4-8 pp. 6, 9 (emphasis in original). 

[TEXT]
<line: 8> The Court of Special Appeals granted the application for leave to appeal on September 23, 
<line: 9> 2015, with respect to one question: 

[TEXT]
<line: 11> Did the post-conviction court err in concluding that defense counsel did not 
<line: 12> provide constitutionally ineffective assistance by failing to investigate and 
<line: 13> present expert testimony to counter expert testimony presented by the State 
<line: 14> that the alleged “victim’s ‘normal’ examination was not inconsistent with 
<line: 15> possible sexual abuse?” 

[TEXT]
<line: 17> ECF No. 4-9. 

[TEXT]
<line: 19> The Court of Special Appeals affirmed the denial of post-conviction relief by reported 
<line: 20> opinion on February 2, 2017, and on May 22, 2017, the Court of Appeals of Maryland denied his 
<line: 21> petition for a writ of certiorari.  Barber v. State, 231 Md. App. 490, 153 A. 3d 800, cert. denied, 
<line: 22> 453 Md. 10, 160 A.3d 547 (2017).   

[TITLE]
<line: 24> II. 
<line: 25> Federal Habeas Petition  

[TEXT]
<line: 27> Mr. Barber filed this § 2254 petition on August 29, 2017, seeking relief on the ground of 
<line: 28> ineffective assistance of trial counsel.  He claims that trial counsel rendered constitutionally 
<line: 29> ineffective assistance in violation of the Sixth Amendment:  (1) by failing to investigate the State’s 
<line: 30> medical expert testimony and by failing to offer a viable defense; (2) by “the admission of 
<line: 31> inaccurate and misleading scientific evidence” in violation of due process; (3) for failing to request 
<line: 32> a limiting instruction for prior inconsistent statements offered by the social workers, the doctor, 
<line: 33> and the victim’s mother; (4) by failing to object when the state made rehabilitative remarks in its 
<line: 34> opening statement and to request a limiting instruction; (5) by failing to object to a witness 
<line: 35> comment about the truthfulness of the victim; (6) for failing to object to the state’s presentation of 

[ABANDON]
<line: 37> 4 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 5 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> expert testimony and delayed reporting and accommodation in child sexual abuse cases; and (7) 
<line: 5> for failing to show Mr. Barber the video recording of the victim’s interview.  ECF No. 1 pp 5-7.  

[TEXT]
<line: 7> Respondents argue that Mr. Barber’s first six claims withstand scrutiny under 28 U.S.C. 
<line: 8> § 2254(d) and the seventh is procedurally defaulted.  

[TITLE]
<line: 10>        PROCEDURAL DEFAULT 

[TEXT]
<line: 12> Before seeking review pursuant to § 2254, a person in custody must exhaust remedies 
<line: 13> available in state court by presenting each claim to the appropriate state court.  A claim is 
<line: 14> procedurally defaulted when a petitioner has failed to present it to the highest state court with 
<line: 15> jurisdiction to hear it, and the state courts would now find that the petitioner cannot assert that 
<line: 16> claim.  Mickens v. Taylor, 240 F.3d 348, 356 (4th Cir. 2001) (quoting Breard v. Pruett, 134 F.3d 
<line: 17> 615, 619 (4th Cir. 1998)).  Procedurally defaulted claims are not subject to substantive federal 
<line: 18> habeas corpus review unless certain exceptions apply to excuse the procedural default.   Procedural 
<line: 19> default may be excused if a petitioner can demonstrate (1) both cause for the procedural default 
<line: 20> and that he will suffer prejudice if the claims are not considered on their merits; or (2) failure to 
<line: 21> consider the defaulted claim(s) would result in a miscarriage of justice, i.e. the conviction of 
<line: 22> someone who is actually innocent of the offenses.  See Murray v. Carrier, 477 U.S. 478, 495-96 
<line: 23> (1986); Gray, 806 F.3d at 709; Breard v. Pruett, 134 F.3d 615, 620 (4th Cir. 1998). 

[TEXT]
<line: 25> Respondents assert that Mr. Barber’s ineffective assistance of counsel claim for failing to 
<line: 26> show him the recording of the victim’s interview is procedurally defaulted.  ECF No. 4 p. 71.  Mr. 
<line: 27> Barber acknowledges in the petition that this claim was not presented to a state court.  ECF No. 1 
<line: 28> p.7.  As he offers no reason why the claim was not raised in state court, nor shows cause to excuse 
<line: 29> procedural default, this claim will be denied and dismissed as procedurally defaulted.  

[ABANDON]
<line: 31> 5 

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 6 of 35

[TITLE]
<line: 4>         STANDARD OF REVIEW 

[TEXT]
<line: 6> The court may grant a petition for a writ of habeas corpus only for violations of the 
<line: 7> Constitution or laws of the United States.  28 U.S.C. § 2254(a) (providing a district court “shall 
<line: 8> entertain an application for a writ of habeas corpus in behalf of a person in custody pursuant to the 
<line: 9> judgment of a State court only on the ground that he is in custody in violation of the Constitution 
<line: 10> or laws or treaties of the United States”).  

[TEXT]
<line: 12> The federal habeas statute sets forth a highly deferential standard for evaluating state court 
<line: 13> rulings, under which state court decisions are to “be given the benefit of the doubt.”  Bell v. Cone, 
<line: 14> 543 U.S. 447, 455 (2005); Lindh v. Murphy, 521 U.S. 320, 333 n.7 (1997).   

[TEXT]
<line: 16> A federal court reviewing a habeas petition that has already been adjudicated 
<line: 17> on the merits in state court [must] give considerable deference to the state court 
<line: 18> decision. A federal court may not grant habeas relief unless the state court 
<line: 19> arrived at a decision that was contrary to, or involved an unreasonable 
<line: 20> application of, clearly established Federal law, as determined by the Supreme 
<line: 21> Court of the United States, or a decision that was based on an unreasonable 
<line: 22> determination of the facts in light of the evidence presented in the State court 
<line: 23> proceeding. 

[TEXT]
<line: 25> Nicolas v. Att’y Gen. of Md., 820 F.3d 124, 129 (4th Cir. 2016) (quoting 28 U.S.C. § 2254(d)).  A 
<line: 26> federal habeas court “must presume that the state court’s factual findings are correct unless the 
<line: 27> petitioner rebuts those facts by clear and convincing evidence,” and “cannot disturb the state 
<line: 28> court’s ruling simply because it is incorrect; it must also be unreasonable.” Id. 

[TEXT]
<line: 30> A state adjudication is “contrary to” clearly established federal law under § 2254(d)(1) 
<line: 31> where the state court “arrives at a conclusion opposite to that reached by [the Supreme] Court on 
<line: 32> a question of law” or “confronts facts that are materially indistinguishable from a relevant Supreme 
<line: 33> Court precedent and arrives at a result opposite to [the Supreme Court].”  Williams v. Taylor, 529 
<line: 34> U.S. 362, 405 (2000) see Lovitt v. True, 403 F.3d 171, 178 (4th Cir. 2005); Barnes v. Joyner, 751 
<line: 35> F.3d 229, 238 (4th Cir. 2014).  A federal court “may not issue the writ simply because [the court] 

[ABANDON]
<line: 37> 6 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 7 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> concludes in its independent judgment that the relevant state-court decision applied established 
<line: 5> federal law erroneously or incorrectly.”  Lovitt, 403 F.3d at 178 (quoting Williams, 529 U.S. at 
<line: 6> 411).  The state court’s application of federal law must be unreasonable, not merely incorrect.  Id.; 
<line: 7> see Barnes, 751 F.3d at 238–39 (state court’s decision is an unreasonable application of clearly 
<line: 8> established federal law when the state court identifies the correct governing principle but 
<line: 9> unreasonably applies that principle to the facts; application of federal law must be objectively 
<line: 10> unreasonable, not merely incorrect). 

[TEXT]
<line: 12> Under section 2254(d)(2), “a state-court factual determination is not unreasonable merely 
<line: 13> because the federal habeas court would have reached a different conclusion in the first instance.”  
<line: 14> Wood v. Allen, 558 U.S. 290, 301 (2010).  “[E]ven if reasonable minds reviewing the record might 
<line: 15> disagree about the finding in question,” a federal court may not conclude that the state court 
<line: 16> decision was based on an unreasonable determination of the facts.  Further, “a determination of a 
<line: 17> factual issue made by a State court shall be presumed to be correct[,]” and the petitioner bears “the 
<line: 18> burden of rebutting the presumption of correctness by clear and convincing evidence.”  28 U.S.C. 
<line: 19> § 2254(e)(1).  “Where the state court conducted an evidentiary hearing and explained its reasoning 
<line: 20> with some care, it should be particularly difficult to establish clear and convincing evidence of 
<line: 21> error on the state court’s part.”  Sharpe v. Bell, 593 F.3d 372, 378 (4th Cir. 2010).  This is especially 
<line: 22> true where the state court has “resolved issues like witness credibility, which are ‘factual 
<line: 23> determinations’ for purposes of Section 2254(e)(1).”  Id.  

[TITLE]
<line: 25>      DISCUSSION  

[TEXT]
<line: 27> “Deciding whether a state court’s decision involved an unreasonable application of federal 
<line: 28> law or was based on an unreasonable determination of fact requires the federal habeas court to 
<line: 29> train its attention on the particular reasons—both legal and factual—why state courts rejected a 

[ABANDON]
<line: 31> 7 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 8 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> state prisoner’s federal claims ... and to give appropriate deference to that decision.”  Wilson v. 
<line: 5> Sellers, 138 S. Ct. 1188, 1191–92 (2018) (internal citations and quotation marks omitted).  A 
<line: 6> federal habeas court’s task under § 2254(d) is “a straightforward inquiry when the last state court 
<line: 7> to decide a prisoner’s federal claims explains its decision on the merits in a reasoned opinion.  Id.   

[TEXT]
<line: 9> The last reasoned decision on the merits of Mr. Barber’s first claim was issued by the Court 
<line: 10> of Special Appeals in the published opinion that affirmed the post-conviction court’s decision. 
<line: 11> Barber, 231 Md. App. at 490, 153 A. 3d at 800; ECF No. 4-13.  The Circuit Court’s Statement of 
<line: 12> Reasons on post-conviction review was the last decision on the merits to consider Mr. Barber’s 
<line: 13> other nonprocedurally defaulted claims.  ECF No. 4-7. 

[TEXT]
<line: 15> In its opinion, the Court of Special Appeals began by recounting the facts adduced at trial, 
<line: 16> on direct review, and during post-conviction proceedings relevant to the question under review.  
<line: 17> ECF Nos. 4-2; 4-3; ECF No. 4-4; ECF No. 4-13.   

[TITLE]
<line: 19> I. 
<line: 20> Trial and Direct Review 

[TEXT]
<line: 22> The victim, G.S., was twelve years old when she testified at trial.  G.S. testified that Mr. 
<line: 23> Barber sexually abused her during the time she was five to nine years old.  Mr. Barber was her 
<line: 24> stepfather and lived with G.S. and her family for several years in different homes in Salisbury, 
<line: 25> Maryland.  The parties stipulated that from June 10, 2003, until July 10, 2004, the family lived on 
<line: 26> Light Street; from July 11, 2004, to January 31, 2007, they lived on Mitchell Street; and from 
<line: 27> February 1, 2007, to April 20, 2009, they lived on Tilghman Street.  ECF No. 4-2 pp. 63, 65-66; 
<line: 28> ECF No. 4-4 p. 2; ECF No. 4-13 p. 3. 

[TEXT]
<line: 30> G.S. testified that when she was five years old and lived on Light Street, Mr. Barber called 
<line: 31> her into the living room and had her remove her pants and underwear.  He was lying on the couch 
<line: 32> wearing only a shirt and boxer shorts.  He placed G.S. on top of him and he started moving her 

[ABANDON]
<line: 34> 8 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 9 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> around.  G.S testified that she felt his “private part” on her vaginal area and testified that “when 
<line: 5> he was putting it in me, it would hurt.  It was hurting.”  ECF No. 4-4 p. 3; ECF No. 4-2 pp. 67-69, 
<line: 6> 72, 75; ECF No. 4-13 p. 3. 

[TEXT]
<line: 8> G.S. testified about two incidents that occurred during the time the family lived on Mitchell 
<line: 9> Street.  The first was when Mr. Barber asked her to lie down in bed with him, took off her 
<line: 10> underwear and “put his private part in my private part and did the same thing over again.”  ECF 
<line: 11> No. 4-2 pp. 77.  The second incident was when he put her on top of him, removed her underwear, 
<line: 12> and put his “private” part in her “private part.”  Id. pp. 77-79.  G.S. stated her “private part” hurt.  
<line: 13> Id. p. 79.  G.S. said she felt something wet and noticed it was white. Id. 79, 80.  Her mother worked 
<line: 14> nights and was not at home at the time.  Upon further questioning, G.S. clarified the term “private 
<line: 15> parts” referred to his penis and her vagina.  Id. p. 79.  

[TEXT]
<line: 17> G.S. testified that when they lived on Tilghman Street, Mr. Barber picked her up in the 
<line: 18> kitchen and “was scooting me down by his private.”  Id. pp. 80-81.  They were clothed at the time, 
<line: 19> but G.S. “felt his private, like kind of scoot-like sticking up.”  Id; ECF No. 4-13 p. 4. 

[TEXT]
<line: 21> Jennifer Wehberg, M.D. was accepted as an expert in pediatric medicine with an emphasis 
<line: 22> on child sexual abuse.  ECF No. 4-2 pp. 115-117; ECF No. 4-13 p. 7.  Dr. Wehberg testified that 
<line: 23> when she examined G.S. on July 2, 2009,2  G.S. described only the initial incident that occurred 
<line: 24> on Light Street.  ECF No. 4-2 pp.  119, 121.  Dr. Wehberg testified that G.S.’s physical examination 
<line: 25> was normal, with no observed lacerations, cuts, redness, discharge, scarring, or evidence of acute 
<line: 26> trauma to the vaginal or rectal area.  Id. pp. 117, 119-120.   

[ABANDON]
<line: 28> 2    At the time of the interview, G.S.’s mother, Tahesha Barber, was estranged from her 
<line: 29> husband Rahymeen Barber.  ECF No. 4-5 p. 12,  n. 1. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 31> 9 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 10 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> Dr. Wehberg confirmed that G.S. told her that she had been penetrated.  Id. p. 120.  Dr. 
<line: 5> Wehberg opined that a “normal” finding was not inconsistent with G.S.’s report that Mr. Barber 
<line: 6> had penetrated her vagina with his penis, explaining that the “vagina is very, vascular and very 
<line: 7> elastic, and can heal very rapidly.  Often within a few days, if you have genital trauma, it can be 
<line: 8> healed to the point where you can't recognize it as trauma.”  Id. pp. 120-121; ECF No. 4-13 p. 7.   
<line: 9> Thus, “[a] normal genital exam can be consistent with penetrating vaginal abuse.”  ECF 4-3 p. 
<line: 10> 128; ECF No. 4-13 p. 7.  

[TEXT]
<line: 12> On cross-examination, Dr. Wehberg was questioned further about the examination: 
<line: 13> Q.  You examined as part of her genital examination, the presence or absence 
<line: 14> of a hymen, correct? 

[TEXT]
<line: 16>       A.  Yes. 
<line: 17>       Q.  And you describe her hymen as crescentic? 
<line: 18>       A.  Crescentic. 
<line: 19>       Q.  Crescentic. Can you tell me what that means? 

[TEXT]
<line: 21> A.  A hymen is a thin membrane of tissue that covers the vaginal opening. 
<line: 22> When you’re very young, your hymen is what we call, annular. It’s circular in 
<line: 23> shape covering the vaginal opening. As you get more into young childhood, it 
<line: 24> becomes a crescent which is a half-moon shape.  It goes over the hymen, and 
<line: 25> you can see a crescent of a thin membrane. 

[TEXT]
<line: 27> Q.  Okay. 

[TEXT]
<line: 29> A. That hymen as you enter puberty again turns into an an[]ular hymen which 
<line: 30> is round. 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> Q.  The genital examination was perfectly normal, correct? 

[TEXT]
<line: 34> A.  Yes, it was.  
<line: 35> Q.  There was, according to the report, no scarring, no damage, is that a fair 
<line: 36> statement? 

[TEXT]
<line: 38> A.  Yes, it is. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 40> 10 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 11 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> Q.  Your opinion or your diagnostic impression is that it is a normal physical 
<line: 5> exam, cannot diagnose or exclude abuse? 

[TEXT]
<line: 7> A.  Right. 
<line: 8> Q.  Is that another way of saying, I don’t know, maybe, maybe not? 

[TEXT]
<line: 10> A.  That’s a way of saying, I can’t tell by her physical exam whether there has 
<line: 11> been sexual abuse.  
<line: 12>       Q.  Can’t confirm? 
<line: 13>       A.  Right. 

[TEXT]
<line: 15> ECF No. 4-2 pp. 125-127; ECF No 4-13 pp. 7-8.   
<line: 16> On redirect examination, this exchange ensued: 

[TEXT]
<line: 18> A.  Are you…familiar with the research regarding medical findings in the 
<line: 19> victim substantiated child sexual abuse? 

[TEXT]
<line: 21> A.  Yes, I am. 
<line: 22> Q.  What does the research say regarding a normal genital exam? 

[TEXT]
<line: 24> A.  A normal genital exam can be consistent with penetrating sexual abuse. 
<line: 25> Q. Is there a percentage of cases in which there are - sex abuse has been 
<line: 26> confirmed but it remains a normal genital exam? 

[TEXT]
<line: 28> A.  It has been shown that you can have a normal vaginal exam with penetrating 
<line: 29> sexual abuse.  I do not know the percentage off my head without the cited article 
<line: 30> in front of me.  

[TEXT]
<line: 32> ECF No. 4-2 pp. 127- 128; ECF No 4-13 pp. 8-9. 

[TEXT]
<line: 34> Heather Sullivan, a social worker at the Wicomico County Child Advocacy Center testified 
<line: 35> that G.S. reported five incidents of alleged sexual abuse.  ECF No. 4-2 p. 136.  When Ms. Sullivan 
<line: 36> first interviewed G.S. on May 19, 2009, and then on July 10, 2009, G.S. told her about the incident 
<line: 37> at the Light Street house.  Id. p. 143.  On January 28, 2010, G.S. told Ms. Sullivan that there had 
<line: 38> been more than the one incident on Light Street.  Id. pp. 149-50.  G.S. told her about an incident 

[ABANDON]
<line: 40> 11 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 12 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> on Mitchell Street when Mr. Barber put her on top of him and his penis came out of a hole in his 
<line: 5> underwear and his private parts touched hers.  Id. p. 151.  G.S. indicated that this incident included 
<line: 6> her performing oral sex on him. Id.   

[TEXT]
<line: 8> Ms. Sullivan testified that G.S. described another incident at the Mitchell Street address 
<line: 9> that involved penetration and ejaculation.  Id. pp. 152, 162-63.  Ms. Sullivan told the court that 
<line: 10> G.S. said Mr. Barber’s penis was hard “did go inside of her,” and reported seeing and feeling a 
<line: 11> white wet substance on her leg.  Id. p. 152.  

[TEXT]
<line: 13> Ms. Sullivan testified that G.S. described to her a fourth incident at the Tilghman Street 
<line: 14> address when appellant had her lie on top of him on the couch and “again moved her up and down, 
<line: 15> privates touching privates, genitals touching genitals.”  Id. p. 154.  A fifth incident also occurred 
<line: 16> at Tilghman Street, when appellant pulled G.S. towards him and their genitals touched through 
<line: 17> their clothing.  Id. p. 155; ECF No. 4-13 p. 4.  

[TEXT]
<line: 19> Tahesha Barber, G.S.’s mother, and Mr. Barber were married from 2004 to August 2010.  
<line: 20> ECF No. 2-4 p. 179.  Ms. Barber testified that G.S. first informed her in 2009 about one incident 
<line: 21> of sexual abuse, and she reported it to the Child Advocacy Center, and G.S. later told her about 
<line: 22> the sexual abuse a second time.  Id. p. 171; ECF No. 4-13 p. 5. 

[TEXT]
<line: 24> Mr. Barber testified at trial.  He denied any of the incidents occurred.  He denied having 
<line: 25> intercourse, oral sex, or sexual relations with G.S.  Id. p. 225.  He testified that he was a father 
<line: 26> figure in the household, the children loved him, and he disciplined them.  Id. p. 237; ECF No. 4-
<line: 27> 13 at 5. 

[TITLE]
<line: 29> III. 
<line: 30> Post-Conviction Hearing 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> The Court of Special Appeals summarized Mr. Barber’s arguments in his Petition for Post-
<line: 33> Conviction Relief, stating:  

[ABANDON]
<line: 35> 12 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 13 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> The only crime of which [Mr. Barber] was convicted that required proof of 
<line: 5> penetration was second-degree rape.  The flagship allegation made in [Mr. 
<line: 6> Barber’s] petition for post-conviction relief dealt with two criticisms:  (1) that 
<line: 7> defense never consulted with an OBGYN or a child sexual abuse specialist; and 
<line: 8> (2) no defense expert was called to refute the opinion of Dr. Wehberg that a 
<line: 9> normal genital exam can be consistent with penetrating sexual abuse. 

[TEXT]
<line: 11> ECF No. 4-13 p. 9.  The court explained that penetration is a necessary element of the crime of 
<line: 12> second-degree rape under Maryland law, citing Kackley v. State, 63 Md. App. 532 (1985) (citations 
<line: 13> omitted).  “Penetration, however slight, will sustain a conviction . . . but the proof thereof must 
<line: 14> sustain a res in re, that is, an actual entrance of the sexual organ of the male within the labia 
<line: 15> (majora) of the pudendum (the external folds of the vulva) of the female organ, and nothing less 
<line: 16> will suffice.”  Craig v. State, 214 Md. 546, 136 A.2d 243 (1957) citing 1 Wharton, Criminal Law 
<line: 17> (l2th ed.), § 697.  “Penetration into either the labia minoria or the vagina is not required; invasion 
<line: 18> of the labia majora, however slight is sufficient to establish penetration.”  Craig, 214 Md at 546.  
<line: 19> ECF No. 4-13 pp.  9-10.3  The Court of Special Appeals then examined the testimony presented at 
<line: 20> trial. 

[TEXT]
<line: 22> A. 
<line: 23> Testimony of Theodore Hariton, M.D. 
<line: 24> Dr. Theodore Hariton, a board-certified obstetrician and gynecologist from Arizona called 
<line: 25> by Mr. Barber as a witness, testified that he had reviewed Dr. Wehberg’s trial testimony, Heather 
<line: 26> Sullivan’s deposition and trial testimony, and G.S.’s trial testimony.  On direct examination, Dr, 
<line: 27> Hariton testified: 

[TEXT]
<line: 29> Q. And after you reviewed it did you arrive at any conclusions regarding 
<line: 30> whether the medical evidence was consistent with penetration?     

[TEXT]
<line: 32> A.  I did.  

[ABANDON]
<line: 34> 3 
<line: 35> On the issue of penetration, the jury at Mr. Barber’s trial was instructed, that “[v]aginal 
<line: 36> intercourse means the penetration of a penis into the vagina.  The slightest penetration is sufficient, 
<line: 37> and the emission of semen is not required.”  ECF No. 4-3 p. 13.  

[ABANDON]
<line: 39> 13 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 14 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> Q.  And what were those conclusions? 

[TEXT]
<line: 6> A. With reasonable medical certainty there’s no medical evidence that penal 
<line: 7> [sic] vaginal penetration occurred at that time. 

[TEXT]
<line: 9> Q. Okay. So it would be unusual for a six-year old or a very young girl to 
<line: 10> have no finding after an episode of nonconsensual penal [sic] vaginal 
<line: 11> penetration? 

[TEXT]
<line: 13> A. Yes, it would. 
<line: 14> Q. And what would you expect the history and physical findings to be that 
<line: 15> would be consistent with vaginal penetration? 

[TEXT]
<line: 17> A. Well, two things.  First of all, the history, you should have pain and 
<line: 18> bleeding.  If you go inside a hymen and tear a hymen in a little girl it will 
<line: 19> bleed and cause pain.  The second thing is it will heal, all of them heal very 
<line: 20> nicely but it will heal with some physical change in shape that will tell you 
<line: 21> something happened in this period of time.  

[TEXT]
<line: 23> Q.  And are both these findings important? 

[TEXT]
<line: 25> A. Yes. 

[TEXT]
<line: 27> Q. And why so? 

[TEXT]
<line: 29> A Well, the history of bleeding, pain, and bleeding is one of the most 
<line: 30> consistent things in all the literature. 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> Q. Okay. 

[TEXT]
<line: 34> A. When you go through the findings you have the history of pain and 
<line: 35> bleeding. 

[TEXT]
<line: 37> Q.  And were these present in this case? 

[TEXT]
<line: 39> A.  No, there was no evidence-I’m sorry, there was nothing in this record 
<line: 40> that I found. 

[TEXT]
<line: 42> Q. What would be the diameter of a vaginal opening in a girl this age? 

[TEXT]
<line: 44> A.  Hymenal opening in a girl in this age would be six or seven millimeters, 
<line: 45> like half the size of your little finger. 
<line: 46> Q.  And what’s the average diameter of an erect male penis? 

[ABANDON]
<line: 48> 14 

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 15 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> A.  35  to 39 millimeters. 

[TEXT]
<line: 6> Q.  It’s about an inch and a half? 

[TEXT]
<line: 8> A.  About an inch and a half, yeah. 
<line: 9> Q.  Okay, so it’s maybe an inch and a half trying to get into a quarter inch 
<line: 10> roughly? 

[TEXT]
<line: 12> A.  Roughly. 
<line: 13> Q.  Now is the hymen stretchable or would it tear if it were penetrated? 

[TEXT]
<line: 15> A.  It is not stretchable.  When you examine a little girl, frequently you’ll 
<line: 16> have to examine and get a specimen with a Q-tip.  And if you touch the 
<line: 17> hymen with your Q-tip, the kid jumps.  It is very delicate and very thin. 

[TEXT]
<line: 19>     ********** 

[TEXT]
<line: 21> Q. Okay.  Now what would a normal six-year old vaginal area look like? 

[TEXT]
<line: 23> A.  Well, the labia majora would be flat, the labia minora is very thin.  The 
<line: 24> whole area is pinkish.  It’s a little redder than an adult because the tissue, 
<line: 25> the vessels are so close to the skin.  It’s very thin, two to three cells thick, 
<line: 26> it’s not stretchable, it’s very easy, it not distensible because there is no 
<line: 27> rigi[dity][4], it won’t stretch.  It’s really vulnerable to any trauma or 
<line: 28> infection.  

[TITLE]
<line: 30>      ********** 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> Q. So what kind of medical evidence could be found after forceful penal 
<line: 33> [sic] vaginal penetration of a girl around six years old? 

[TEXT]
<line: 35> A.  What you should see is depending if it’s a complete laceration or not- 
<line: 36> Q.  Could you speak a little bit slower? 

[TEXT]
<line: 38> A.  Okay, I’m sorry. It depends on the depth of the penetration, how far it 
<line: 39> went.  It doesn’t fit so therefore it can’t go very far.  But it can tear.  If it’s 
<line: 40> a transection, which means it goes all the way through the hymen down to 
<line: 41> the vagina, then you’ll see that the hymen is a circle like this, and would be 
<line: 42> a totally completed circle.  If you tear, do a transection, it means you cut all 
<line: 43> the way through here, this would be the vagina, and when they heal it will 
<line: 44> still heal like this but it will heal with a section, there won’t be any hymen 
<line: 45> here at all. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 47> 4  Alteration added. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 49> 15 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 16 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> And if not totally sometimes you just have a very deep notch right in that 
<line: 5> area that’s easy to see.  It will all heal so it will be smooth, but it will be a 
<line: 6> change. 

[TEXT]
<line: 8> Q. So there would be some kind of- 

[TEXT]
<line: 10> A.  Physical evidence, yes. 
<line: 11> Q.  There would be some kind of result, some kind of evidence left- 

[TEXT]
<line: 13> A. Yes.  
<line: 14> Q.  – if this happened, okay is there anything in the reports that you read 
<line: 15> that suggests that there was actual penal [sic] vaginal penetration 

[TEXT]
<line: 17> ECF No. 4-6 pp. 20-26; ECF No. 4-13 pp. 10-13.  Additionally, Dr. Hariton expressed his 
<line: 18> disagreement with aspects of Dr. Wehberg’s testimony. 

[TEXT]
<line: 20> First and most important, she said that the hymen of a little girl is very 
<line: 21> vascular and elastic.  It is not elastic, it’s not stretchable at all, and it’s not 
<line: 22> vascular.  It looks a little pinker than the rest of the tissue because it’s so 
<line: 23> thin blood, the vessels that are there are closer to the surface.  But it’s not 
<line: 24> stretchable. 

[TEXT]
<line: 26> ECF No. 4-6 p. 26; ECF No. 4-13 p. 14. 

[TEXT]
<line: 28> Dr. Hariton disagreed with Dr. Wehberg’s testimony.  He disagreed that medical literature 
<line: 29> states there can be “penal [sic] vaginal penetration in a prepubertal girl without any physical 
<line: 30> findings” and cited to several publications in support of his position.  ECF No. 4-6 p. 27-31; ECF 
<line: 31> No. 4-13 p. 14.  Asked whether he was “comfortable in saying there’s no medical evidence of 
<line: 32> vaginal penal [sic] penetration” of G.S., Dr. Hariton responded that he saw no evidence of “penal 
<line: 33> [sic] vaginal penetration.”  ECF No. 4-6 p. 31.  

[ABANDON]
<line: 35> 16 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 17 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> On cross examination, Dr. Hariton testified that there should be scarring if there is injury 
<line: 5> to the hymen in a prepubertal girl.  The amount of scarring will be different depending on the age, 
<line: 6> estrogen, and amount of damage to the girl.  ECF No. 4-6 p. 41; ECF No. 4-13 pp. 15-16.   

[TEXT]
<line: 8> A.  So if there is superficial injury to the hymen will a physician be able to 
<line: 9> see scarring?   
<line: 10> Q.  It may or may not form a notch, a superficial notch.  But a penis can’t 
<line: 11> get in a little -- a 39 millimeter penis can't get into a six millimeter hymen 
<line: 12> with a superficial injury. 

[TEXT]
<line: 14> A.  And I will go ahead and inform you penetration is defined in the state 
<line: 15> of Maryland as entrance into the labia minor. 
<line: 16> Q.  Okay. 

[TEXT]
<line: 18> A.  So while I appreciate your definition that it’s you know, penile 
<line: 19> penetration in the vagina, that is not what’s legally required in the State of 
<line: 20> Maryland. 

[TEXT]
<line: 22> A  That’s but to a juror I think penetration means penetration.  The word 
<line: 23> penetration means to enter.  It means to enter. 

[TEXT]
<line: 25> Q.  It means however slight in the State of Maryland, Dr. Hariton. 

[TEXT]
<line: 27> A.  Okay. 
<line: 28> Q.  So it does not require piercing, puncture or any injury to the hymen, just 
<line: 29> so that you’re clear. 

[TEXT]
<line: 31> A. Okay.      
<line: 32>      ************ 
<line: 33> Q.  [What is] [t]he primary way that physicians diagnose sexual abuse? 

[TEXT]
<line: 35> A.  By the history and by the examination. 
<line: 36> Q.  By patient history [?] 

[TEXT]
<line: 38> A.  Patient history and examination. 
<line: 39> Q.  The timing of the examination, is that crucial to determining whether 
<line: 40> there was penetration?  

[ABANDON]
<line: 42> 17 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 18 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> A.  If you examine a child at the acute phase of contact you’ll see a different 
<line: 5> set of findings, just penile contact or touching you’ll have bruising, a little 
<line: 6> staining, a little bit of this, and it heals very quickly.  But actual penetration 
<line: 7> by this time it’s healed.  There’s a short period of time it takes to heal the 
<line: 8> small stuff. 

[TEXT]
<line: 10> Q.  So things heal very quickly in the hymen or the vaginal area correct? 

[TEXT]
<line: 12> A.   Reasonably quickly.  Again depending on the child and the injury. 

[TITLE]
<line: 14> ************  

[TEXT]
<line: 16> Q.  … Did you view the photographs Dr. Wehberg took in this case? 

[TEXT]
<line: 18> A.  No, I never got the photographs.

<line: 20> of scarring. 

[TEXT]
<line: 22> A.  Yes, I saw that.

<line: 24> that she could not confîrm or deny that abuse had happened in this case? 

[TEXT]
<line: 26> A.  That is correct. 
<line: 27> Q.  Is that accurate, would that be an accurate statement? 

[TEXT]
<line: 29> A.  Without any findings you can’t confirm or deny? ... I said without any 
<line: 30> findings you can neither confîrm nor deny that there was sexual activity.  In 
<line: 31> this case you can deny penile vaginal penetration but you couldn’t deny 
<line: 32> sexual contact. 

[TEXT]

[TEXT]

<line: 18> Evaluation of the Sexually Abused Child would you turn to page 120, 
<line: 19> please? 

[TEXT]

[TEXT]
<line: 23> And captioner under sexual abuse delayed disclosure. 

[TEXT]
