[TEXT]
<line: 27> That paragraph discusses findings in chronic, in cases of chronic sexual 
<line: 28> abuse, is that correct? 

[TEXT]
<line: 30> A. The first edition, this chapter was called sexual abuse chronic changes. 
<line: 31> This edition she’s changed that to sexual abuse delayed disclosure.  So the 
<line: 32> two books, the chronic changes, that’s why she says what we term chronic 
<line: 33> changes in the previous edition 

[TEXT]
<line: 35> Q.  If you will read for the Court that paragraph.  

[TEXT]
<line: 37> A. What we termed chronic conditions in the previous edition was better 
<line: 38> described as medical findings associated with healed genital trauma.  Since 
<line: 39> most children delay disclosure, medical professionals are typically asked to 
<line: 40> evaluate a child long after injuries should have healed.  However, as noted 
<line: 41> previously, where there has been significant trauma associated with vaginal 
<line: 42> penetration, healed disruptions of the posterior fourchette, vestibular 
<line: 43> mucosa, hymen, and anus may be found.  

[TEXT]
<line: 45> Q.   May be found. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 47> 19 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 20 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> A.  Yes. 
<line: 5> Q.  So a normal genital exam can be consistent with penetrating vaginal 
<line: 6> abuse, is that correct? 

[TEXT]
<line: 8> A. I’ve never seen that written.  It would depend on how much penetration 
<line: 9> we’re talking about.  We’re talking about the child.  The amount of 
<line: 10> penetration, how the child heals. 

[TEXT]
<line: 12> Q.  Is it possible, is my question? 

[TEXT]
<line: 14> A.  I don’t know, I’ve never seen it, never seen it written.  
<line: 15> Q.  Based on your experience and your review of the literature, it can be 
<line: 16> consistent?   
<line: 17> A.  It’s a very hard question because I’ve never seen it, never seen it happen, 
<line: 18> and the tendency in medicine is to always say never say never.  

[TEXT]
<line: 20> ECF No. 4-6 p. 51-53, ECF No. 4-13 pp. 15-19.   

[TITLE]
<line: 22> B. 
<line: 23> Testimony of Trial Counsel  

[TEXT]
<line: 25> Mr. Barber’s trial counsel, Archibald G.W. McFadden, testified to having 17 years of trial 
<line: 26> experience, familiarity with the literature on sexual abuse of young girls, and significant 
<line: 27> experience handling child abuse cases for the Public Defender’s Office in Wicomico County.  ECF 
<line: 28> No. 4-6 pp. 16-15; ECF No. 4-13 pp. 20-21, 58-59, 61. 

[TEXT]
<line: 30> On direct examination, Mr. McFadden testified that he did not consider consulting with a 
<line: 31> child abuse specialist expert in this case.  ECF No. 4-6 pp. 61; ECF No. 4-13 p. 20.  He told the 
<line: 32> post-conviction court that he reviewed Dr. Wehberg’s report finding that G.S.’s hymen was normal 
<line: 33> and that sexual abuse could neither be diagnosed nor excluded, and “was satisfied with the results” 
<line: 34> of the report.  ECF No. 4-6 p. 61.  Trial counsel testified that his theory of the case was that the 
<line: 35> State could not prove beyond a reasonable doubt that G.S. was sexually abused.  ECF No. 4-6 p. 
<line: 36> 62; ECF No. 4-13 pp. 19-20. 

[TEXT]
<line: 38> On cross examination by the State and later on redirect, he testified: 

[ABANDON]
<line: 40> 20 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 21 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> Q.  Why didn’t you consider consulting with an expert in Mr. Barber’s case? 

[TEXT]
<line: 6> A.  Personally, I didn’t think I needed to. 
<line: 7> Q.  Why? 

[TEXT]
<line: 9> A. There were all the elements in place in this case, in my opinion, we should 
<line: 10> have won.  And Dr. Wehberg’s opinion I was generally satisfied with. 

[TEXT]
<line: 12>     ************ 

[TEXT]
<line: 14> Q.  You said you had a hard time winning these in front of juries.  In your 
<line: 15> experience what’s the deciding factor for a jury in a case where there’s no 
<line: 16> physical evidence? 

[TEXT]
<line: 18> A.  I would say I don’t think there’s one - personally I don’t believe that 
<line: 19> there’s one deciding factor.  I think if what is in place is a reason for the 
<line: 20> victim to fabricate or make it up, there’s a lack of physical evidence, there’s 
<line: 21> an articulate criminal defendant who can testify, all of those factors are 
<line: 22> significant.  And if you have, as I did in this case, I had all of those factors, 
<line: 23> I think they all play together.  

[TEXT]
<line: 25>    ************ 

[TEXT]
<line: 27> Q. Knowing what you know now would you do anything different in this 
<line: 28> case? 

[TEXT]
<line: 30>    ************ 

[TEXT]
<line: 32> A. Would I do anything different?  I, in reviewing the documentation, I 
<line: 33> would have cross-examined the victim differently.  I probably would have 
<line: 34> been more aggressive.  And I hope I that I would have won. 

[TEXT]
<line: 36> Q.  Did you treat Mr. Barber’s case different than any other in which you 
<line: 37> have defended individuals in the last 17 years? 

[TEXT]
<line: 39> A.  No. Mr. Barber’s case was a serious case and I actually like Mr. Barber 
<line: 40> very much as an individual.  So no, I did not treat it differently than I would 
<line: 41> treat any other serious case.  

[TEXT]
<line: 43> ECF No. 4-6 pp. 65-66; ECF No. 4-13 pp. 22-23.     

[ABANDON]
<line: 45> 21 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 22 of 35

[TITLE]
<line: 4> III. 
<line: 5> Analysis 

[TEXT]
<line: 7> The Sixth Amendment to the United States Constitution affords a criminal defendant the 
<line: 8> right to “Assistance of Counsel.”  U.S. Const. amend. VI.  The Supreme Court has stated that 
<line: 9> “assistance which is ineffective in preserving fairness [of a trial] does not meet the constitutional 
<line: 10> mandate.”  Mickens v. Taylor, 535 U.S. 162, 166 (2002).  In Strickland v. Washington, 466 U.S. 
<line: 11> 668 (1984), the Court explained that to show constitutionally ineffective assistance of counsel, a 
<line: 12> petitioner must show both deficient performance and prejudice—that “counsel made errors so 
<line: 13> serious that counsel was not functioning as the ‘counsel’ guaranteed the defendant by the Sixth 
<line: 14> Amendment,” id. at 687, and that “there is a reasonable probability that, but for counsel’s 
<line: 15> unprofessional errors, the result of the proceeding would have been different.”  Id. at 694. 

[TEXT]
<line: 17> To satisfy the deficient performance prong of the Strickland standard, a defendant must 
<line: 18> show “that counsel’s representation fell below an objective standard of reasonableness.” 
<line: 19> Kimmelman v. Morrison, 477 U.S. 365, 375 (1986).  “Judicial scrutiny of counsel’s performance 
<line: 20> must be highly deferential” and not based on hindsight.  Strickland, 466 U.S. at 689.  “[A] court 
<line: 21> must indulge a strong presumption that counsel’s conduct falls within the wide range of reasonable 
<line: 22> professional assistance.”  Id.  A petitioner “... must overcome the presumption that, under the 
<line: 23> circumstances, the challenged action ‘might be considered sound trial strategy.’”  Id.  Decisions 
<line: 24> made by counsel may be subject to second-guessing with the benefit of hindsight; however, 
<line: 25> counsel’s tactical and strategic choices made after due consideration do not constitute ineffective 
<line: 26> assistance of counsel, and there is a strong presumption that counsel’s conduct was within the wide 
<line: 27> range of reasonable professional assistance.  Id. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 29> 22 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 23 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> Under the Sixth Amendment, a defendant “has a right to effective representation, not a 
<line: 5> right to an attorney who performs his duties ‘mistake-free.’”  Weaver v. Massachusetts, 137 S. Ct. 
<line: 6> 1899, 1910 (2017) (quoting United States v. Gonzalez-Lopez, 548 U.S. 140, 147 (2006)).  

[TEXT]
<line: 8> To satisfy the prejudice prong of the Strickland standard, a petitioner must show “that there 
<line: 9> exists a reasonable probability that, but for counsel’s unprofessional errors, the result of the 
<line: 10> proceeding would have been different.”  Kimmelman, 477 U.S. at 375.  “The essence of an 
<line: 11> ineffective-assistance claim is that counsel’s unprofessional errors so upset the adversarial balance 
<line: 12> between defense and prosecution that the trial was rendered unfair and the verdict rendered 
<line: 13> suspect.”  Kimmelman, 477 U.S. at 374.  A determination whether the attorney’s performance was 
<line: 14> deficient need not be made if it is clear that there was no prejudice.  See Strickland, 466 U.S. at 
<line: 15> 697. 

[TEXT]
<line: 17> “The standards created by Strickland and § 2254(d) are both highly deferential, and when 
<line: 18> the two apply in tandem, review is doubly so.”  Harrington v. Richter, 562 U.S. 86, 105 (2011) 
<line: 19> (internal citations omitted).  “When § 2254(d) applies, the question is not whether counsel’s 
<line: 20> actions were reasonable.  The question is whether there is any reasonable argument that counsel 
<line: 21> satisfied Strickland’s deferential standard.”  Id.    

[TITLE]
<line: 23> A. 
<line: 24> Failure to Investigate the State’s Medical Expert Claim 

[TEXT]
<line: 26> On post-conviction review Mr. Barber argued that expert testimony countering Dr. 
<line: 27> Wehberg's opinion would have helped to present a valid defense to the rape charge, and also bolster 
<line: 28> counsel’s attack on G.S.’s credibility as to whether any abuse occurred at all.  He argued that his 
<line: 29> trial counsel was deficient because, had he consulted with a medical expert, he would have found 
<line: 30> a basis to challenge Dr. Wehberg’s testimony as inconsistent with G.S.’s allegations.  Specifically, 
<line: 31> an expert like Dr. Hariton could have disputed Dr. Wehberg’s testimony that a little girl’s hymen 

[ABANDON]
<line: 33> 23 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 24 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> is very vascular and elastic, as well as her claim that medical literature supported her testimony 
<line: 5> that penile vaginal penetration in a prepubertal girl can occur without any physical findings.  Mr. 
<line: 6> Barber further argued that counsel’s strategy was unreasonable because further investigation and 
<line: 7> efforts to counter Dr. Wehberg’s conclusions would not have detracted from the stated trial 
<line: 8> strategy.  ECF No. 4-13 p. 27.  

[TEXT]
<line: 10> The State countered that trial counsel’s strategy not to consult an expert was part of a 
<line: 11> legitimate trial strategy, and Mr. Barber failed to prove the strategy was uninformed or 
<line: 12> unreasonable. No. 4-13 pp. 26-27.  

[TEXT]
<line: 14> Applying the Strickland standard, the Court of Special Appeals examined trial counsel’s 
<line: 15> performance, taking note of his experience defending sexual abuse cases, his review of Dr. 
<line: 16> Wehberg’s report, and his decision to defend Mr. Barber by impeaching G.S. to demonstrate her 
<line: 17> lack of credibility to convince the jury the State had failed to prove Mr. Barber’s guilt beyond a 
<line: 18> reasonable doubt.  The Court of Special Appeals rejected Mr. Barber’s contention that had trial 
<line: 19> counsel consulted a medical expert like Dr. Hariton, or relevant medical literature, trial counsel 
<line: 20> could have found information that a prepubertal girl could not have a normal genital exam after 
<line: 21> penetration, stating that “[c]ontrary to Dr. Hariton’s testimony, there was ample medical literature 
<line: 22> from very reputable peer reviewed medical journals that supported Dr. Wehberg’s opinion.”  ECF 
<line: 23> 4-13 pp. 35-36 (citations to medical journals omitted).  The court stated: 

[TEXT]
<line: 25> A competent criminal defense lawyer representing a defendant in a case like this 
<line: 26> one, should, upon receipt of a report by a medical expert like Dr. Wehberg, consult 
<line: 27> an independent expert under some, but not all, circumstances.  One of the 
<line: 28> circumstances where an expert should be consulted would be if the lawyer is 
<line: 29> unfamiliar with the medical literature concerning the issue about which the State’s 
<line: 30> expert is prepared to testify.  In this case, trial counsel testified that he was presently 
<line: 31> familiar with the relevant medical literature.  But trial counsel was never asked 
<line: 32> about what he did know.  Except for trial counsel’s testimony, there was no other 
<line: 33> direct or circumstantial evidence on this subject.  Because appellant failed to show 
<line: 34> that at the time of his 2010 trial his counsel was unfamiliar with the pertinent 

[ABANDON]
<line: 36> 24 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 25 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> literature, the State was entitled to the benefit of the presumption that trial counsel’s 
<line: 5> performance (in so far as it covered medical research) was professional and 
<line: 6> competent.  State v. Peterson, 158 Md. App. 55g (2004). 

[TEXT]
<line: 8> ECF No. 4-13 pp. 37-38.  Turning to the related issue of what trial counsel should have known in 

[TEXT]
<line: 10> 2010, had he consulted the relevant literature, the court stated: 

[TEXT]
<line: 12> There is nothing in the record to show that what Dr. Wehberg said about the vaginal 
<line: 13> area was in error.  So no matter how much research [Mr. Barber’s] trial counsel had 
<line: 14> done, the State’s expert could not have been effectively cross-examined on that 
<line: 15> point.  Appellant takes a contrary view, which is based on Dr. Hariton’s testimony. 
<line: 16> Dr. Hariton said that Dr. Wehberg was wrong when she said that “the hymen of a 
<line: 17> little girl is very vascular and elastic.”  But, contrary to what Dr. Hariton testified 
<line: 18> to, Dr. Wehberg never testified that the hymen is “very vascular” and “elastic.”  She 
<line: 19> testified that the “vaginal area is very vascular and very elastic and can heal very 
<line: 20> rapidly.”  As the State points out, appellant’s argument is like comparing apples to 
<line: 21> oranges. 

[TEXT]
<line: 23> Id. pp. 38-39.   

[TEXT]
<line: 25> In regard to Mr. Barber’s contention that trial counsel should have consulted with and 
<line: 26> called a witness who would have testified as Dr. Hariton did at the post-conviction hearing, the 
<line: 27> court concluded: 

[TEXT]
<line: 29> In our view, G.S.’s testimony did not make it clear that there was “forceful 
<line: 30> penetration” through the hymen.  See Adams, supra, at 32L (“Young children have 
<line: 31> no concept of what is meant by the term in the vagina.  A statement such as ‘he put 
<line: 32> his thing in my privates may or may not mean that full penetration occurred.’”).  If 
<line: 33> there had been forceful penetration into the vagina, as both Dr. Hariton and Dr. 
<line: 34> Wehberg agree, there would have been bleeding - and G.S. did not report bleeding. 
<line: 35> As already pointed out, to prove second-degree rape in Maryland, proof of 
<line: 36> penetration through the hymen is not necessary.  And, even Dr. Hariton does not 
<line: 37> contend that two years after the event that there would be signs of trauma, if the 
<line: 38> hymen is not ruptured.  Under such circumstances, it is far from clear what would 
<line: 39> have been gained if [Mr. Barber’s] counsel had found a doctor who would have 
<line: 40> contradicted Dr. Wehberg and said that if there is penetration of the hymen there 
<line: 41> will be evidence of that penetration in a post-rape examination. 

[TEXT]
<line: 43> Id. p. 39-40. 

[TEXT]
<line: 45> Trial counsel testified that in his analysis Mr. Barber’s case involved all three factors 
<line: 46> necessary successfully to defend a child abuse case:  (1) a reason for the victim to fabricate; (2) 

[ABANDON]
<line: 48> 25 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 26 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> lack of physical evidence to support the victim’s allegations; and (3) an articulate criminal 
<line: 5> defendant who can testify.  His strategy was to focus on G.S.’s lack of candor.  The court 
<line: 6> determined that trial counsel set forth a reasonable basis for his trial strategy.   

[TEXT]
<line: 8> It would not, of course, be considered sound trial strategy to not consult with a 
<line: 9> physician if something said in Dr. Wehberg’s report was manifestly in error or 
<line: 10> that she held an opinion that a reasonably competent lawyer, familiar with the 
<line: 11> relevant literature, should have recognized as invalid.  As shown, it is far from 
<line: 12> clear that any opinion Dr. Wehberg gave was in error.  At the time of trial (and 
<line: 13> presently) some, but not all, experts in her field agreed with Dr. Wehberg that 
<line: 14> a normal physical exam does not exclude the possibility of past penile 
<line: 15> penetration of the hymen.  Because of a significant number of journal articles 
<line: 16> supporting Dr. Wehberg’s views, calling an OBGYN who shared Dr. Hariton’s 
<line: 17> opinions would be risky inasmuch as such opinion could be contradicted, or at 
<line: 18> least undermined by the literature discussed, supra. 

[TEXT]
<line: 20> Id. p. 41. 

[TEXT]
<line: 22> Applying the Strickland standard, the court observed that when counsel’s decision is based 
<line: 23> upon partial investigation, the resulting tactical decision remains presumptively reasonable 
<line: 24> “precisely to the extent that reasonable professional judgments support the limitations on 
<line: 25> investigation.”  Strickland, 466 U.S. at 691.  In other words, representation is not ineffective if 
<line: 26> based on a reasonable investigation or “a reasonable decision that makes particular investigations 
<line: 27> unnecessary.”  Id.  Even a decision not to investigate is entitled to “a heavy measure of deference 
<line: 28> to counsel’s judgment.”  Id.  By focusing his efforts on establishing reasonable doubt, trial counsel 
<line: 29> did not provide ineffective assistance, even if the trial strategy did not result in a successful 
<line: 30> outcome for his client.  Thus, the court concluded Mr. Barber had failed to demonstrate that 
<line: 31> counsel’s representation fell below an objective standard of reasonableness to meet the 
<line: 32> performance prong of the Strickland test.  Having concluded that Mr. Barber failed to meet the 
<line: 33> performance prong of the Strickland standard, the Court of Special Appeals determined it 
<line: 34> unnecessary to consider the prejudice prong.  ECF No. 4-13 pp. 40-43. 

[ABANDON]
<line: 36> 26 

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 27 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> The court reached its conclusion after properly stating the Strickland standard, and the 
<line: 5> court’s application of that standard to the facts of the case was reasonable.  Having examined the 
<line: 6> state court’s ruling as well as having independently examined the record, this court is satisfied that 
<line: 7> in applying the Strickland standard to Mr. Barber’s allegations, the state court reasonably 
<line: 8> concluded that counsel made a strategic decision not to consult other witnesses, which a court will 
<line: 9> not second guess.  Stamper v. Muncie, 944 F.2d 170, 178 (4th Cir. 1991) (challenge to counsel’s 
<line: 10> trial decisions and tactics amounted to no more than “Monday morning quarter backing”).  The 
<line: 11> state court’s ruling survives scrutiny under the standards announced in Strickland and set forth at 
<line: 12> § 2254(d).  Accordingly, this claim for relief will be denied.  

[TITLE]
<line: 14> B. 
<line: 15> Failure to Object to Admission of Inaccurate Evidence Claim 

[TEXT]
<line: 17> Mr. Barber next claims that counsel was ineffective for failing to object to the admission 
<line: 18> of inaccurate and misleading scientific evidence that violated his right to due process.  Mr. Barber 
<line: 19> claimed that Dr. Wehberg’s testimony was misleading “because it was based on her 
<line: 20> misunderstanding of the generally accepted methodology for diagnosis of anatomical findings in 
<line: 21> relation to prior sexual acts,” and its admission violated his right to due process.  ECF No. 4-5 p. 
<line: 22> 25; see also ECF No. 4-7 at 10. 

[TEXT]
<line: 24> In rejecting this claim, the post-conviction court determined that this evidence was not 
<line: 25> inaccurate or misleading, and found the case law on which Mr. Barber premised his due process 
<line: 26> claim involved convictions based on “patently incorrect numerical data.”  ECF No. 4-7 p. 10.  In 
<line: 27> contrast, Dr. Wehberg was a properly qualified expert with sufficient factual basis to support her 
<line: 28> expert medical opinion.   

[TEXT]
<line: 30> The Petitioner’s disagreement with Dr. Wehberg’s testimony, and the claim that 
<line: 31> contrary expert testimony could have refuted it, quite simply, does not make 
<line: 32> Dr. Wehberg’s testimony inadmissible, or establish that it does not conform to 
<line: 33> generally accepted scientific norms.  As discussed above, Dr. Hariton’s 

[ABANDON]
<line: 35> 27 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 28 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> testimony at the Post-Conviction hearing, at most, merely cast doubt on Dr. 
<line: 5> Wehberg’s testimony and certainly did not provide a basis to render that 
<line: 6> testimony inadmissible.  Further, Mr. McFadden reasonably concluded that he 
<line: 7> could rely on Dr. Wehberg’s inconclusive finding regarding abuse to argue that 
<line: 8> reasonable doubt existed.  Thus, he had no reason to object to the testimony, as 
<line: 9> he could rely on her opinion in arguing for an acquittal.  

[TEXT]
<line: 11> Id.  

[TEXT]
<line: 13> In the absence of a reason to object to the testimony, trial counsel was not ineffective for 
<line: 14> failing to object.  The state court found counsel’s trial strategy was reasonable and his decision not 
<line: 15> to raise an objection was consistent with this strategy.  Mr. Barber does not meet his burden to 
<line: 16> show the state court decision was “contrary to, or involved an unreasonable application of, clearly 
<line: 17> established Federal law, as determined by the Supreme Court of the United States” or “was based 
<line: 18> on an unreasonable determination of the facts in light of the evidence presented in the State court 
<line: 19> proceeding.”  28 U.S.C. § 2254(d).  This claim provides no grounds for habeas relief.  

[TITLE]
<line: 21> C. 
<line: 22> Ineffective Assistance for Failing to Object to Prior Inconsistent Statements 

[TEXT]
<line: 24> Mr. Barber’s third claim for federal habeas relief is that trial counsel was ineffective for 
<line: 25> failing to request a limiting instruction that prior inconsistent statements offered by Dr. Wehberg, 
<line: 26> Ms. Sullivan, the social worker, and Tahesha Barber, the victim’s mother, were not intended for 
<line: 27> the truth that the abuse actually occurred.  Additionally, he faults trial counsel for failing to object 
<line: 28> to G.S.’s testimony that she told her mother and sister about the abuse.  The Circuit Court denied 
<line: 29> this claim for lack of merit because G.S’s statements to Dr. Wehberg and Ms. Sullivan were 
<line: 30> admissible for the truth of the matter asserted under Md. Code Ann., Crim. Pro.  § 11-304.  The 
<line: 31> State Court noted that the evidence was properly admitted under the evidentiary laws of Maryland, 
<line: 32> and thus trial counsel could not be ineffective for failing to object.  

[TEXT]
<line: 34> Trial counsel does not provide ineffective assistance by failing to raise a meritless 
<line: 35> objection.  Oken v. Corcoran, 220 F.3d 259, 269 (4th Cir. 2000) (“[T]rial counsel was not 

[ABANDON]
<line: 37> 28 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 29 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> constitutionally ineffective in failing to object ... because it would have been futile for counsel to 
<line: 5> have done so.”); Truesdale v. Moore, 142 F.3d 749, 756 (4th Cir. 1998) (“It is certainly reasonable 
<line: 6> for counsel not to raise unmeritorious claims”.).  Further, because these objections would have 
<line: 7> been denied had they been made, Mr. Barber cannot show a reasonable probability of a different 
<line: 8> outcome to satisfy the prejudice prong of Strickland.  

[TEXT]
<line: 10> Turning to trial counsel’s decision not to object to Tahesha Barber’s testimony about G.S.’s 
<line: 11> statements, the post-conviction court found counsel’s action consistent with his stated trial 
<line: 12> strategy.  “ …[G.S.’s] allegations were largely unsubstantiated and there was no physical evidence 
<line: 13> to corroborate her story.  Ms. Barber’s testimony as well as [G.S.’s] testimony left Mr. McFadden 
<line: 14> ample room to argue reasonable doubt,” therefore, the court concluded that trial counsel’s 
<line: 15> “decision whether or not to object … was within, his sound discretion.”  ECF No. 4-7 p. 12.  The 
<line: 16> post-conviction court’s conclusion that the failure to object to statements made to Ms. Barber was 
<line: 17> part of a reasonable trial strategy given the circumstances and substance of those statements is 
<line: 18> entitled to deference under § 2254(f) and Strickland.  Accordingly, federal habeas relief is denied 
<line: 19> as to this claim.    

[TITLE]
<line: 21> D. 
<line: 22> Failing to Object to Witness Comments Claim 

[TEXT]
<line: 24> Mr. Barber’s fourth claim is that trial counsel was constitutionally deficient for failing to 
<line: 25> object to comments made during the State’s opening statement and to request a limiting instruction.  

[TEXT]
<line: 27> The State’s opening statement began: 

[TEXT]
<line: 29> [G.S.] will testify today.  I expect that she will tell you what she was eventually 
<line: 30> able to tell Child Protective Service worker Heather Sullivan that her stepfather, the 
<line: 31> defendant seated before you today, began to abuse her at age 5 and it continued for 
<line: 32> years. 

[TEXT]
<line: 34> I say eventually because [G.S.] initially made a disclosure and was questioned in 
<line: 35> May and July of 2009.  She was questioned at the Child Advocacy Center by 

[ABANDON]
<line: 37> 29 

[TITLE]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 30 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> Heather Sullivan, Child Protective Service Worker, and then once an exam, a 
<line: 5> medical exam was completed by Dr. Jennifer Wehberg. 

[TEXT]
<line: 7> [G.S.] told Sullivan and Wehberg about one event of sexual abuse. She didn’t tell 
<line: 8> everything.  

[TEXT]
<line: 10> But that's not unusual, ladies and gentlemen.  You will hear today from Catherine 
<line: 11> Beers who is a licensed clinical social worker.  She is an expert in the field of Social 
<line: 12> Work and Child Sexual Abuse.  

[TEXT]
<line: 14>     ********** 

[TEXT]
<line: 16> Keep in mind, she was five when the abuse began, five years old, or was it that she 
<line: 17> didn’t feel supported by her mother, that her mother didn’t want to believe her, 
<line: 18> didn’t want to believe the person that she married and loved could commit such 
<line: 19> horrific acts upon her child? 

[TEXT]
<line: 21> I expect you will hear that [G.S.]’s mother, Tahesha Barber, even after [G.S.]’s 
<line: 22> initial disclosure in May and July of 2009 that Tahesha continued to see the 
<line: 23> defendant. ... Keep in mind that she is 12 years old and she was 5 when the abuse 
<line: 24> began.  I make no promises as to exactly what she will be able to tell you today. 

[TEXT]
<line: 26>     ********** 

[TEXT]
<line: 28> You will also, in addition to hearing from G.S. hear from Heather Sullivan, the 
<line: 29> social worker in this case.  You will hear from Dr. Wehberg, and you will hear from 
<line: 30> Cathy Beers ...   

[TEXT]
<line: 32> ECF No. 4-5 p. 29.  The Circuit Court in its Statement of Reasons found no merit to Mr. Barber’s 
<line: 33> claims regarding the State’s opening statement.   

[TEXT]
<line: 35> The Petitioner alleges that the Assistant State’s Attorney, in her opening 
<line: 36> statement, “. . . effectively - and prejudicially - set the stage to rehabilitate [the 
<line: 37> victim’s] vague allegations.”  Petition, 21.  The Petitioner cites Maryland Rule 5- 
<line: 38> 616(c)(2), which indicates that there are three prerequisites to the admission of a 
<line: 39> prior statement as rehabilitation:  (1) the witness’ credibility must have been 
<line: 40> attacked; (2) the prior statement is consistent with the trial testimony; and (3) the 
<line: 41> prior statement detracts from the impeachment.  According to the Petitioner, these 
<line: 42> prerequisites were not satisfied.  After careful review of the transcript and 
<line: 43> consideration of the arguments, the Court finds that the State’s remarks in opening 

[ABANDON]
<line: 45> 30 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 31 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> statement were not improper, and thus Mr. McFadden’s failure to object is not 
<line: 5> ineffective assistance of counsel. 

[TEXT]
<line: 7> At the outset, the Court notes that the Petitioner has mischaracterized the 
<line: 8> prosecutor’s statements as rehabilitative.  The challenged remarks were that “she 
<line: 9> [the victim] didn’t tell [Sullivan and Wehberg] everything” and “I make no 
<line: 10> promises as to exactly what she [the victim] will be able to tell you today.”  In 
<line: 11> making these remarks, the Assistant State’s Attorney merely outlined what she 
<line: 12> expected the jury to hear that day, which embodies the very purpose of opening 
<line: 13> statements.  See White v. State, 11 Md. App. 423, 274 A.2d 671 (1971) (noting that 
<line: 14> opening statements are to advise the jury as to what it may expect by way of 
<line: 15> evidence and questions which will be presented to it). 

[TITLE]
<line: 17> ECF No. 4-7 p. 13. 

[TEXT]
<line: 19> The court also rejected Mr. Barber’s claim that trial counsel was deficient for failing to 
<line: 20> challenge the admissibility of prior out of court statements, for reasons already discussed in regard 
<line: 21> to Md. Code Ann., Crim. Pro. § 11-304. supra.  Lastly, the court found Mr. Barber’s claim that 
<line: 22> trial counsel was ineffective by failing to object and preserve the issue for appeal had no merit.  
<line: 23> Because the evidence and testimony were admissible, counsel was not ineffective for failing to 
<line: 24> object where there was no legal basis to a grant relief.  ECF No. 4-7 p. 13. 

[TEXT]
<line: 26> As already discussed, trial counsel does not provide ineffective assistance by failing to 
<line: 27> object to admissible evidence and testimony.  The state court ruling was neither contrary to, nor 
<line: 28> involved an unreasonable application of applicable Supreme Court precedent, nor was it based on 
<line: 29> an unreasonable determination of the facts in light of the evidence presented in the State court 
<line: 30> proceeding.  The state court decision is based on facts well-supported in the record and premised 
<line: 31> on a reasonable application of Strickland to those facts.    

[TITLE]
<line: 33> E. 
<line: 34> Failure to Object to Witness’ Comment Claim 

[TEXT]
<line: 36> As to his fifth claim, Mr. Barber contends that trial counsel rendered ineffective assistance 
<line: 37> by failing to object to Tashesa Barber’s comments on the truthfulness of the victim.  When 

[ABANDON]
<line: 39> 31 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 32 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> questioned at trial regarding what she said when G.S. told her of the sexual abuse, Ms. Barber 
<line: 5> answered: 

[TEXT]
<line: 7> Word for word, I don’t remember exactly what I told [G.S.].  I know that I was 
<line: 8> confident to [G.S.] when she told me.  I had gotten a little bit confused when 
<line: 9> you said May as to which time it was that she had said it.  She disclosed 
<line: 10> information to me twice.  May was the first time that she told me.  And the first 
<line: 11> time that she told me, I was just, you know, I was confused, you know.  She 
<line: 12> had just told me that, you know, my husband had touched her, and I didn’t want 
<line: 13> to believe it the first time she told me, you know.  But at the same time that’s 
<line: 14> my child so I was confident to [G.S.] and confused at the same time which was 
<line: 15> the reason why I reported it to the child advocacy center because I didn’t know 
<line: 16> what to do. 

[TEXT]
<line: 18> ECF No. 4-2 p. 171; ECF No. 4-7 p. 14. 

[TEXT]
<line: 20> The court found that Ms. Barber’s statements did not “constitute clear vouching” for G.S.’s 
<line: 21> truthfulness.  ECF No 4-7 p. 15.  Although the “plain meaning” of the comment that Ms. Barber 
<line: 22> “was confident to [G.S.] is not completely discernible,” the court continued that “if a reasonable 
<line: 23> inference can be drawn that Ms. Barber was commenting on [G.S.’s] truthfulness,” trial counsel’s 
<line: 24> failure to object was not ineffective assistance.  The court concluded that an objection would not 
<line: 25> likely have affected the outcome of trial.”  Id.  

[TEXT]
<line: 27> Mr. Barber next claimed that the prosecutor erred during closing argument by 
<line: 28> reemphasizing the victim’s credibility when she said: “Mother never doubted [the victim’s] 
<line: 29> credibility.  She didn’t want to believe her, but she never doubted that [the victim] was telling the 
<line: 30> truth.  Tr. 9/2/10, 35.”  Id.  The court found no error in admitting these statements as prosecutors 
<line: 31> are generally granted “liberal freedom of speech and may make any comment that is warranted by 
<line: 32> the evidence or inferences reasonably drawn therefrom.”  Spain v. State, 386 Md. 145, 152-3 
<line: 33> (2005) (quoting Degren v. State, 352 Md. 400, 429-30 (1999)).  Further, “[a]lthough courts have 
<line: 34> disapproved of the prosecutor ‘vouching’ for the credibility of a witness, courts have emphasized” 
<line: 35> that evaluating witness credibility “is often a transcendent factor in the factfinder’s decision 

[ABANDON]
<line: 37> 32 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 33 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> whether to convict or acquit a defendant” and counsel is permitted to “comment on or attack 
<line: 5> witness credibility by examining motive not to tell the truth.”  Id. at 154.  The Circuit Court found 
<line: 6> the prosecutor was not vouching for witness credibility, but merely commenting on the fact that 
<line: 7> G.S.’s mother believed her daughter.  The mother’s testimony was in evidence, and therefore, 
<line: 8> properly the subject of closing argument for both the State and the defense.  For these reasons, the 
<line: 9> court determined there was no error in admitting Ms. Barber’s statements or in the prosecution’s 
<line: 10> reference to them in closing argument, and trial counsel did not provide ineffective assistance by 
<line: 11> failing to raise an objection.  ECF No. 4-7 pp. 15-16. 

[TEXT]
<line: 13> As discussed supra, trial counsel’s failure to raise an objection that is without merit does 
<line: 14> not constitute deficient performance.  The post-conviction court’s decision is not “contrary to, or 
<line: 15> involved an unreasonable application of, clearly established Federal law, as determined by the 
<line: 16> Supreme Court of the United States,” nor is it “a decision that was based on an unreasonable 
<line: 17> determination of the facts in light of the evidence presented in the State court proceeding.”  28 
<line: 18> U.S.C. § 2254(d).  This claim provides no cause to award federal habeas relief and will be denied.  

[TITLE]
<line: 20> F. 
<line: 21> Failure to Object to Expert Testimony about Delayed Reporting Claim 

[TEXT]
<line: 23> Mr. Barber’s sixth claim is that trial counsel was deficient for failing to object to testimony 
<line: 24> by social worker Catherine Beers about delayed disclosure of sexual abuse.  Mr. Barber posits that 
<line: 25> counsel should have objected to Ms. Beers’ explanations concerning why G.S. delayed reporting 
<line: 26> sexual abuse, child abuse accommodation syndrome, and her conclusive statement supporting 
<line: 27> G.S.’s credibility. ECF No. 1 p. 6; ECF No. 4-5 pp. 16-17.  

[TEXT]
<line: 29> Mr. Barber argued in his post-conviction petition that Ms. Beers had not met anyone in the 
<line: 30> family and had not read any reports about the case.  Her testimony was based on her expertise in 
<line: 31> the subject matter and sitting through the trial, and was accepted without objection by trial counsel 

[ABANDON]
<line: 33> 33 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 34 of 35

[TEXT]
<line: 4> even though G.S. “had already given a common sense reason that she did not disclose the alleged 
<line: 5> abuse earlier; “I was scared.”  ECF No. 4-5 pp. 16-17. 

[TEXT]
<line: 7> The Circuit Court concluded trial counsel’s determination not to object to Ms. Beers’ 
<line: 8> testimony did not constitute ineffective assistance.  Ms. Beers was accepted by the court as an 
<line: 9> expert in clinical social work and child abuse (ECF No. 4-2, pp. 186-189), and her statements were 
<line: 10> admissible as expert testimony under Md. Rule 5-702, which permits admission of expert 
<line: 11> testimony in the form of an opinion or otherwise, if the testimony will assist the trier of fact to 
<line: 12> understand evidence or a fact at issue.  The Circuit Court further noted that a trial counsel’s failure 
<line: 13> to object “generally indicates that defense counsel felt that the trial error was not critical to his 
<line: 14> client’s case; presumably, therefore, the error did not render the trial fundamentally unfair.”  Engle 
<line: 15> v. Isaac, 456 U.S. 107, 137 (1982), “The decision to interpose objections during trial is one of 
<line: 16> tactics and trial strategy.”  Oken v State, 343 Md. 256, 295 (1996).  “The Court cannot find that 
<line: 17> [trial counsel’s] decision not to object to Ms. Beers’ testimony rises to the level of ineffective 
<line: 18> assistance of counsel.”  ECF No. 4-7 pp. 16-17.    

[TEXT]
<line: 20> This court may not grant habeas relief unless it finds that the state court decision “was 
<line: 21> contrary to, or involved an unreasonable application of, clearly established Federal law” or 
<line: 22> “resulted in a decision that was based on an unreasonable determination of the facts in light of the 
<line: 23> evidence presented in the State court proceeding.”  28 U.S.C. § 2254(d)(1).  Under these 
<line: 24> circumstances, the court finds no error in the state post-conviction court’s determination.  The state 
<line: 25> post-conviction court’s determination is well supported by the record.  The state post-conviction 
<line: 26> court’s findings are presumptively correct and withstand scrutiny pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 2254(d) 
<line: 27> and (e).   

[ABANDON]
<line: 29> 34 

[ABANDON]
<line: 2> Case 8:17-cv-02491-DKC   Document 11   Filed 09/02/20   Page 35 of 35

[TITLE]
<line: 4>          CERTIFICATE OF APPEALABILITY 

[TEXT]
<line: 6> Rule 11(a) of the Rules Governing § 2254 Cases states that the district court “must issue 
<line: 7> or deny a certificate of appealability when it enters a final order adverse to the applicant” in such 
<line: 8> cases.  28 U.S.C. § 2253(c)(2).  To obtain a certificate of appealability, a habeas petitioner must 
<line: 9> make a substantial showing of the denial of a constitutional right.  Buck v. Davis, 137 S. Ct. 759, 
<line: 10> 773 (2017); Slack v. McDaniel, 529 U.S. 473, 483–84 (2000).  When a district court rejects 
<line: 11> constitutional claims on the merits, a petitioner satisfies this standard by demonstrating that “jurists 
<line: 12> of reason could disagree with the district court’s resolution of his constitutional claims or that 
<line: 13> jurists could conclude the issues presented are adequate to deserve encouragement to proceed 
<line: 14> further.”  Buck, 137 S. Ct. at 773.  When a petition is denied on procedural grounds, the petitioner 
<line: 15> meets this standard by showing that reasonable jurists “would find it debatable whether the petition 
<line: 16> states a valid claim of the denial of a constitutional right” and “whether the district court was 
<line: 17> correct in its procedural ruling.”  Slack, 529 U.S. at 484.   

[TEXT]
<line: 19> Mr. Barber’s claims are denied and dismissed on both procedural grounds and upon the 
<line: 20> merits.  Upon review of the record, he has not made the requisite showing to warrant a certificate 
<line: 21> of appealability as to any of his claims, and the court declines to issue one.  He may request that 
<line: 22> the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit issue such a certificate.  See Lyons v. 
<line: 23> Lee, 316 F.3d 528, 532 (4th Cir. 2003). 

[TITLE]
<line: 25> CONCLUSION  

[TEXT]
<line: 27> For these reasons, the court will, by separate order, deny and dismiss the petition and 
<line: 28> decline to issue a Certificate of Appealability. 

[TEXT]
<line: 30> September 2, 2020 

[ABANDON]
<line: 32> __________/s/_____________________ 
<line: 33> DEBORAH K. CHASANOW 
<line: 34> United States District Judge 

[ABANDON]
